In an interview you did with English music website Line Of Best Fit two years ago, you said that you use music in your acting all the time. Can you explain how?
In very simple ways, really. I suppose, to expand on what I said earlier, music helps me to get into that emotional space that you need to get into for a part. I will find a song or a number of songs that, I think, will help me get to the place that I need to get to for a scene or for a character. Then I‚Äôll just put them on and they‚Äôll help in the preparation, or they‚Äôll help step into that headspace.
For example, this film that I was doing this summer is set in 1978, so all the cast have put together a Spotify playlist of all tunes from 1978. We just had that music on all the time. We discovered all these amazing tunes, like bands I‚Äôd never heard of, and really famous tunes as well.
Then, when I‚Äôm doing theater, I might have one song that I listen to just before I go onstage to get me into the space.
‚Äú In terms of choices that you make as an actor, I‚Äôve always been much more inspired by musicians than other actors. ‚Äù
No, I don‚Äôt think I use it as a tool. It‚Äôs more like a source of inspiration or sort of, something to help me along. And, you know, in terms of choices that you make as an actor, I‚Äôve always been much more inspired by musicians than other actors, in terms of attitude, outlook and just doing the work that you want to do. And trying not to take the easy choices.
That‚Äôs interesting, because if you think about it, a lot of musicians are playing a character onstage. So there‚Äôs like a big similarity between acting and playing onstage. When you go to a gig, do you sometimes see some kind of acting onstage that you particularly relate to?
Oh, completely. I think it‚Äôs different for different bands. Some bands are very, very theatrical, and some bands are not. But there are always elements of performance, particularly for the lead singer. There‚Äôs always that element of sort of‚Ä¶ going outside yourself. Sometimes, it‚Äôs very obvious that the singer is playing a character. And sometimes it‚Äôs not.
What I like about live performance ‚Äì and it‚Äôs different in films ‚Äì is that sort of transcendence, where the performer and the audience kind of click, and all of a sudden they‚Äôre outside themselves. It‚Äôs really rare and it doesn‚Äôt happen that often, but it‚Äôs what I chase in theater all the time, and also when I go to a gig. When it‚Äôs a really good gig and the music is just surging through you, that‚Äôs when it‚Äôs special.
I‚Äôm going back to when you started acting : you saw A Clockwork Orange (the musical play adapted from the book by Anthony Burgess himself ‚Äì Ed.) in Cork when you were younger and you said in different interviews that it‚Äôs the first play that made a big impression. Do you think it was also because of the big part music plays in it?
I don‚Äôt recall if there were songs, if it was like a musical‚Ä¶ It certainly had a lot of music in it, because it was set in a very famous nightclub in Cork called Sir Henry‚Äôs. They knocked it down but it was a major venue for dance music and and alternative music in general ‚Äì Nirvana played there back in the day, opening for Sonic Youth. It was such a great club.
They had the play upstairs and it was just dark. There was a DJ and they had all this dry ice, all these guys on stilts, some guys had Mohicans‚Ä¶ It was promenade theater, you weren‚Äôt just sitting down. The ‚Äúdroogs‚Äù (‚Äúfriends‚Äù in Nadsat, the fictional argot Burgess invented for A Clockwork Orange ‚Äì Ed.) were kind of like intimidating you and following you around. It was the most exciting thing I‚Äôd ever experienced. I couldn‚Äôt believe that I was experiencing this thing. And then, I immediately went to the theater company and asked for an audition, but I don‚Äôt recall if the music played a special role in impressing me that much.
In the book, the play or in the movie, A Clockwork Orange‚Äôs lines have a crazy musicality, mostly because of the slang Burgess used in it. Do you pay attention to the musicality and the rhythm of the lines while reading a script or a play?
Yeah, for sure. It‚Äôs really important. In fact, in the first play that I did, called Disco Pigs (by Enda Walsh ‚Äì Cillian also played in Kirsten Sheridan‚Äôs movie, adapted from the play ‚Äì Ed.), my character was talking in this kind of invented language, a cross between Cork slang and baby-talk. You could probably say that it was inspired by Burgess‚Ä¶ And it was very, very musical. Language is the second most important tool you have as an actor, your body being the first, so its musicality is important, yeah.
When you‚Äôre learning lines or reading a script for the first time, does the flow of the words sound like a song in your head?
I think everything has a rhythm, but there‚Äôs such a huge difference between acting on stage and acting in films. They‚Äôre very different disciplines. Beckett has actually famously said that it‚Äôs not about meaning, it‚Äôs about rhythm. People we‚Äôre always asking: ‚ÄúWhat does this mean in your plays?‚Äú. And he said: forget the meaning and think about the rhythm. And he would particularly say that to his actors. It makes a lot of sense, particularly when you‚Äôre performing, for some reason, things would just click with another actor, and all of a sudden, you‚Äôre in this rhythm together, and it clicks with the audience. It‚Äôs not about what the message is. The language is doing the work for you, like a song.
What happens when the flow or the rhythm of a line feels wrong to you? Do you talk to the director about it?
Yeah. This movie I was doing this summer, Free Fire, is directed by Ben Weathley. He‚Äôs written it as well so it‚Äôd say: ‚ÄúLook, can I just say it in my own words, because it‚Äôs not really sitting right in my mouth. Can I just say it this way?‚Äù You still deliver the same information, but you‚Äôre just doing it in a slightly different way, and he was cool with it. It‚Äôs just about trying to find the truth in it. It can never sound false, I guess.
‚Äú I have a problem with biopics in general, musician biopics, because my opinion is always, ‚ÄúGo and listen to the records. They‚Äôll be more interesting than some actor in a terrible wig.‚Äù ‚Äù
There‚Äôs a common thing, between a lot of the movies you‚Äôre in: they‚Äôre always linked to music in some way. Either because they‚Äôre set in a certain music era, like in Breakfast on Pluto (in which his character evolves in the glam rock scene ‚Äì Ed.) or Hippie Hippie Shake (film about Richard Neville‚Äôs life as the editor-in-chief of famous 60s satyric magazine Oz ‚Äì Ed.), or because you play, sing or pretend to play in it, like in Disco Pigs, The Edge Of Love (by John Maybury, 2008 ‚Äì Ed.) or Watching The Detectives. Is it something that particularly attracts you in a movie?
Yes, there has been a bit of that. I can‚Äôt help it, I love playing the guitar or sing (laughs). But it has to make sense within the film. So I wouldn‚Äôt take a job just to do that. It has to be a good story. I‚Äôve happened to do it in a couple of films, but that wouldn‚Äôt be my reason for taking the film.
I‚Äôve also been offered a few biopics and musicals in the past. I think I‚Äôve been very careful about choosing those. I have a problem with biopics in general, musician biopics, because my opinion is always, ‚Äúgo and listen to the records. They‚Äôll be more interesting than some actor in a terrible wig‚Äù (laughs).
For me, watching a Scorsese documentary on George Harrison or Bob Dylan is far more revealing than a proper movie. I think it‚Äôs impossible to convey somebody‚Äôs whole life in 90 minutes. Maybe if you pick a segment of their life, sometimes it works. But I‚Äôve always been of the opinion that if you listen to the records, or watch a good documentary, it‚Äôs better than a fictionalized version of a musician‚Äôs life. This tends to be reductive. It never works for me.
Have you ever seen 24-hour Party People (by Michael Winterbottom, movie released in 2002 which tells the story of Manchester music scene through the life of Tony Wilson, creator of famous Factory Records label ‚Äì Ed.)? It‚Äôs a very hybrid movie between documentary, fiction and mockumentary. What do you think about this way of celebrating music?
Yeah, that worked. Again, I‚Äôd be very careful about it, but that is a good example, I think, of one that works. But there‚Äôs not a lot of them.
First of all, I think you need to be able to play (laughs) ! I hate when guitar players can‚Äôt play or sing. You know who was really good? Oscar Isaac in that Coen Brothers movie (Inside Llewyn Davis, 2013 ‚Äì Ed.). He really played and sang. I thought he was brilliant in that film. I think that‚Äôs essentially what you need to know about music to play a musician.
‚Äú In that scene at the end of Sunshine, where the sun is coming towards them and it‚Äôs like ecstatic and weird (‚Ä¶), we were listening to a lot of Sigur Ros and really intense classical music insanely loud to try to get that feeling of what that might be like. ‚Äù
Going back to what you were saying about having a playlist on Spotify on set this summer, does that kind of playlist also help you build your character‚Äôs background, or see the world as he sees it?
Again, it‚Äôs more about the feelings, more about the way these songs make you feel. And then using that. In that scene at the end of Sunshine where the sun is coming towards them and it‚Äôs like ecstatic and weird, when Robert (the character he plays ‚Äì Ed.) knows he‚Äôs going to die, but actually thinks it‚Äôs like some communion with nature, Danny (Boyle ‚Äì Ed.) was like: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve got to find the most euphoric music to shoot this !‚Äù So we were listening to a lot of Sigur R√≥s and really intense classical music insanely loud to try to get that feeling of what that might be like. That‚Äôs how I try to, or how our directors will try to use music.
You‚Äôve acted in movies with great scores ‚Äì Sunshine, Inception, Broken or Tron: Legacy (by Joseph Kosinski, 2010 ‚Äì Ed.). Do you pay attention to scores when you sign in for a movie?
It‚Äôs the director‚Äôs call, who‚Äôs going to score the film. But I‚Äôm always really excited when it‚Äôs somebody that I like. I mean I‚Äôm a huge Blur fan, so I thought that was amazing that Damon Albarn did the music for Broken. And I love Daft Punk (who did Tron: Legacy soundtrack ‚Äì Ed.).
I think the directors need to know how to use music correctly, though. I don‚Äôt really like when there‚Äôs music all over a film. Then it‚Äôs telling you how to feel. I don‚Äôt really like that.
I do this TV show called Peaky Blinders (which tells the story of a family gang in Birmingham ‚Äì Ed.). It‚Äôs set in the 1920s in Britain. I remember when they told me they were going to use contemporary music on it ‚Äì The White Stripes, Nick Cave, Tom Waits, Arctic Monkeys, The Kills : I was like ‚ÄúNo! You can‚Äôt put contemporary music on period!‚Äù (laughs). But then I watched it, and it works. It really really works.
Would you say that this contemporary music helps connect the audience to the show and break the historical barrier?
Yeah, I think you‚Äôre probably right. It probably does help. What also helps is the fact that these characters are quite outlaw characters, and the music that the directors have put in it is kind of outlaw, rock‚Äôn‚Äôroll stuff too, particularly in the second season. I was really happy with the music in that, because it was more like PJ Harvey.
You actually brought Flood (producer of PJ Harvey, Nick Cave, Depeche Mode records, amongst others ‚Äì Ed.) on board for the soundtrack of the second season, right ?
Yeah, Flood is a good friend of mine. The director (Colm McCarthy ‚Äì Ed.) loves PJ Harvey, so I said I could maybe ask him. I did, and then he asked Polly, and she said she‚Äôd loved to do it, so that‚Äôs kind of how it came about (laughs). It‚Äôs lovely when that happens.
Well, I helped put them together, yeah, which was nice. And, you know, it got to be PJ Harvey, which was pretty cool. I thought that having a female voice on the second season was really nice as well, because it‚Äôs such a brutal show in many ways. I think the contrast does work.
Did you adjust your acting once you knew Peaky Blinders was going to feature contemporary music? Or is it something that you don‚Äôt pay attention to?
The latter. That‚Äôs all to do with the edit. You have to find the truth in the character onscreen, and then trust the director to cut it, and trust whoever‚Äôs doing the score to put it right. In the second season, ‚ÄúRed Right Hand‚Äù by Nick Cave became the team track, so that was always sort of a mood. But I‚Äôd have to leave that to the director for the cut, really.
No! (He laughs) Because you don‚Äôt really know what the opening scene credits are going to be, you know? It would be probably a little risky to start thinking like, I‚Äôm going to walk in a certain manner so it‚Äôll suit the song.
Do the emotions you get from a script translate into music in your head? Have you ever thought ‚Äúoh, that scene would go so well with this song‚Äù while reading a script?
I‚Äôm constantly going around listening to songs and going ‚ÄúOh wow, that would be such a great song for a soundtrack‚Äú, or ‚ÄúWhenever I direct or write my own film, I‚Äôm going to ask this guy to do a soundtrack‚Äù or ‚ÄúWouldn‚Äôt that be amazing over this element‚Äú. I‚Äôm always thinking about it like that, but when I read a script, first, I try to concentrate on if the story makes sense. The music stuff comes later.
Yeah, he‚Äôs just actually done one now (Victoria soundtrack, by Sebastian Schipper, released this year ‚Äì Ed.), so I didn‚Äôt get him in time, but Nils Frahm.
We know Nils very well here at Blogoth√®que! We filmed him for one of our Pocket Parties a while ago. Have you guys ever met?
I‚Äôve been communicating with him over email. I‚Äôve never actually met him but I interviewed him for a magazine. He did a Late Night Tales compilation, and I‚Äôm doing the spoken word on it, at the end, written by my friend Enda Walsh. I‚Äôve never seen him live. I just missed him in Dublin. I‚Äôve missed him so many times through work, which is really frustrating, but hopefully, in the future, I will see him live. I have all his albums. He‚Äôs really, really special.
It‚Äôs not the first time you‚Äôve collaborated with a musician. You got involved in Orbital‚Äôs Paul Hartnoll new project, 8:58 ‚Äì you talk on some of his songs, right? How did this go?
Paul just sent me this piece of text while I was shooting. I didn‚Äôt hear the music, he just sent me the text, so I recorded it into my iPhone (laughs) and sent it back as a sort of a demo to say ‚ÄúLook, do you want it like this?‚Äù Him and Flood, who produced that record as well, said ‚ÄúWe love it, we‚Äôre going to put it on!‚Äù So it‚Äôs just a recording on an iPhone, which is kind of great. Again, I love the way technology can do that nowadays. I just picked a mood for it. Paul wanted it kind of slightly ominous, you know. So it was really quick. And then he cut the song around it, or kind of edited the song around it. I love it because it‚Äôs like an old school Orbital dance song. It makes you want to dance.
You were also featured in one of his music videos, ‚ÄúThe Clock‚Äù. How is acting in a music video different than acting in a movie or a play?
I did a couple of music videos. I did one with Feist for her song ‚ÄúThe Water‚Äù a few years ago (Cillian also appears briefly in I Break Horses‚Äô ‚ÄúWinter Beats‚Äù music video ‚Äì Ed.) but that was very different. Paul had this idea, and we shot it in one day. There was a lot of silly dancing involved, and I always love dressing up, so it was a bit of fun. I loved Orbital growing up, and I like doing things like that, when you‚Äôre friends. Nobody‚Äôs doing it to make any money. It‚Äôs just about making this little tiny piece to go with this song, and it‚Äôs just people who both like each other‚Äôs work. We just had a bit of fun and he‚Äôs a friend of mine, and I really liked it.
‚Äú I have a long history of trying to make friends with musicians, because I‚Äôm just like a groupie. ‚Äù
‚ÄúThe Water‚Äù must have been a very special experience because it‚Äôs not a classic music video: it was directed by a musician, Broken Social Scene‚Äôs Kevin Drew, and it‚Äôs surprisingly about the absence of music as half of it is silent. How was it to be involved in this video?
Well, the story of that is‚Ä¶ (he bursts into laughter). I have a long history of trying to make friends with musicians, because I‚Äôm just like a groupie (laughs). Kevin Drew interviewed me for some magazine. I‚Äôm a huge fan of Broken Social Scene music, so then, we just became friends. I used to go and see their shows, and we‚Äôd meet up after. That‚Äôs how I met Leslie, when she was playing with them.
Kevin had this idea for that song. He called me so I just flew to Canada and we shot it. It was kind of a film to accompany the song. It was not really like your classic music video. We had a lovely time out in the snow, shooting it. Kevin is a really good director. He should make a feature film, because he‚Äôs that talented. He has all these fantastic stories in his head. He‚Äôll sit you down, drink a bottle of wine, and he‚Äôll just tell you all these different films, scene after scene after scene. He‚Äôs a really smart guy. People just didn‚Äôt know what to make of this video I guess, because not much happened in it. I think that‚Äôs a really beautiful little film.
Yeah, I did. We also listened to it a lot while we were shooting, and we listened to other music as well, like Brian McBride. We were in the woods, in the snow, Kevin had his little boombox, and we were playing this really kind of sad Brian McBride music while we were shooting the scene in which the mother and the son say goodbye to each other. You can‚Äôt do that while shooting a film, but the great thing about a music video is there‚Äôs never any sound.
And then you went on the other side of the camera to direct Money‚Äôs music video, ‚ÄúHold Me Forever‚Äù. Why did this band and this song in particular attract you as a director?
I‚Äôve always wanted to direct a music video. And I was telling that to Simon (Raymonde, founder of Money‚Äôs label, Bella Union ‚Äì Ed.), but I was like, it has to be the right song. Because if I don‚Äôt feel strongly enough about it then I don‚Äôt want to invest all this time and effort into it. He sent me ‚ÄúHold Me Forever‚Äù and he said : ‚ÄúWell I think you might like this one‚Äù This song is so emotional. It blew me away. I couldn‚Äôt stop listening to it. So I said ‚ÄúAbsolutely, let‚Äôs do it‚Äù I met Jamie (Lee, Money‚Äôs leader ‚Äì Ed.) and we really got on. I didn‚Äôt have an idea at the time, but then I just kept listening to the song, and all of a sudden, I thought about ballet dancers, which is funny because I had never been to the ballet at that time (laughs). I‚Äôve gone since, but I just thought it would be really nice. I called Jamie, and he said he really liked the idea.
Generally I don‚Äôt like music videos when the band are in them. I think it‚Äôs much more interesting when they‚Äôre not. Or if the band are in them, I like when they‚Äôre not playing, when they‚Äôre actually doing something else. I don‚Äôt generally like narrative music videos either. I think it‚Äôs better if they‚Äôre just images, but that‚Äôs just sort of my personal preference.
Anyway, so that‚Äôs kind of how it came about. I loved directing this video. I loved going and renting the truck, picking up the cameras, the lights, getting everyone to work for free, going to the edit and going to the grade ‚Äì all of those things that you never get to see as an actor, because you just turn up, learn your lines, say them, and then go home to your hotel. It was very different.
For me, Money‚Äôs songs are both really powerful and intimate at the same time. Was the fact that you chose to film dancers in close-ups a way to recreate the two sides of Money‚Äôs music?
Well, I wish I had thought of that (laughs). It makes a lot of sense. I suppose the music was speaking to me like that. When you look at these ballet dancers, they‚Äôre so unbelievably strong, but at the same time, they‚Äôre so fragile, so small and so delicate. I was fascinated by that. I love close-ups in film. I think it‚Äôs so powerful. I can watch close-ups for hours ‚Äì if you put the camera close up to someone, you can just watch them think or move. I find it really stunning. I‚Äôm not really interested in a wide shot, I don‚Äôt know why. So it just seemed to work for the song: it‚Äôs very much about yearning and longing ‚Äì I think you get that a lot in performances as well. The song is about reaching for something, and I felt that we‚Äôd try and convey that in the dancers. They‚Äôre reaching for this kind of perfection, but their bodies are always limiting them, to what they can really achieve.
As a director, did you see the movements of the camera as a kind of dance? Like, it had to have rhythm, just like in ballet?
Yeah, it was very interesting. I wanted the camera to be moving all the time. And then I thought it was very important to cut it with the song, but not like obviously to the song. Do you know what I mean?
Because it shouldn‚Äôt be sign-posted or telegraphed. You should let the audience or whoever‚Äôs watching it feel it for themselves. You shouldn‚Äôt cut straight away on a beat, but to cut off the beat, I think is important.
You should do one of our Take Away Shows! We won‚Äôt pay you either and we‚Äôll let you rent the truck and edit the video yourself (laughs)! Well, you never know! Again, it has to be something that I absolutely adore. And then, you have to be able to get on with the band. So yeah, I would like to do it, but the thing is that it takes a lot of time, organizing it.
Oh, yeah, so many. Actually, I think I did a playlist for that Line of Best Fit interview with ‚ÄúCoffee & TV‚Äù by Blur, ‚ÄúLotus Flower‚Äù by Radiohead. I love this one in which Thom Yorke is dancing.
Apart from Sigur Ros during the Sunshine shoot, is there a band or a song that you keep going back to and that is linked to a particular movie you did?
It really depends. I love certain albums that remind me of certain films. I kind of curate them for each project. Each has a different playlist or radio station that I make up, so it changes. Recently, I‚Äôve been listening a lot to this Irish band, The Frames, that I used to love growing up. I hadn‚Äôt listened to them for a long time. Their songs are really powerful, and it really snaps me back to being 25 again. I like to do that with albums you haven‚Äôt listened to for a long time. Then you come back and realize why you loved them in the first place.
If you could get Danny Boyle, he would be great to talk to. He‚Äôs one of the guys that I‚Äôve worked with that is unbelievable passionate about music. If you think about the Trainspotting soundtrack and how he used music there‚Ä¶ And Danny got Godspeed You! Black Emperor to play the opening sequence in 28 Days Later ! Those guys had never been on a soundtrack before. It was the only time they ever allowed their music to be on a film.
I just saw them play in Dublin a few months ago and they were unbelievable. Five guitarists, two bass players, two drummers‚Ä¶ It was a wave, a tsunami of sound. It was beautiful. And they played the track from 28 Days Later (‚ÄúEast Hastings ‚Äì Ed.) at the start. This film is very special to me. I haven‚Äôt watched it in ten years so hearing that track live brought me back. It reminded me how powerful their music is. And then I met them afterward ‚Äì they were cool guys.
Going back to Danny, he‚Äôs got such a brilliant ear for music. He‚Äôs made quite a few iconic scenes in cinema, through music. People will never forget Trainspotting. It‚Äôs never got old. The last time I watched it, it didn‚Äôt seem dated to me at all. It seemed really fresh. So yeah, try to speak to Danny, he‚Äôs a busy man but he loves talking about music.
Cillian Murphy will be starring in Matthew Joy new film In The Heart of the Sea on December, 9th, 2015, as well as in Ben Wheatley‚Äôs Free Fire, Jozef Gabƒç√≠k‚Äôs Anthropoid, and Peaky Blinders season 3, all expected for 2016.
You can also listen to the mixtape he just did on Fractured Air website for Sounds From A Safe Harbour Festival, curated by The National‚Äôs Bryce Dessner (his previous mixtapes are here and here.)
And a big thank you to photographer Richard Gilligan who kindly allowed us to use his beautiful shot of Cillian at the beginning of this article. Go see his amazing work on his website: www.richgilligan.com
US President Donald Trump speaks at a dinner with business leaders at Trump National Golf Club in Bedminster, New Jersey, August 7, 2018. /VCG Photo
The US-China trade dispute seems to have escalated since July 6, and the US has been ‚Äúincreasing its stakes‚Äù by first announcing the imposition of additional 25-percent tariffs on 34 billion US dollars‚Äô worth of Chinese products, and then announcing a further 10-percent increase in tariffs on 200 billion US dollars in Chinese imports. The Trump administration is reported to be considering tariffs on more Chinese goods.
The aggressive attitude of the US appears to show the world its confidence in winning the trade war. However, there are divergent views within the country: the US Congress, the Trump administration, the American business community and the affected states have all voiced their dissatisfaction with the trade conflict and their opposition against Donald Trump‚Äôs radical trade policies.
Members of the US Congress are already anxious about Trump‚Äôs unpopular protectionist trade policies. In recent days, Republican and Democratic Congress members have frequently voiced their opposition in hopes of reducing the negative impact of Trump‚Äôs trade protectionism.
On July 11, the Senate voted 88-11 to constrain Trump‚Äôs presidential authority to use national security as justification for taxing foreign goods, which unusually secured bipartisan support. Though non-binding, this effort highlighted the concern of US lawmakers about Trump‚Äôs radical trade policies.
It is not just members of Congress who disagree with Trump‚Äôs trade policies. Even within Trump‚Äôs negotiating team, there is disagreement over whether to launch a trade war.
Wilbur Ross, the Commerce Secretary and a China hand, was believed to be dovish and was openly criticized by Trump for being soft on China. Terry Branstad, currently the US ambassador to China, is also seen as dovish, mainly because he comes from a state that exports large quantities of agricultural products to China and he has maintained friendly relations with the Chinese business community and government. Steven Mnuchin, Secretary of the Treasury who worked at Goldman Sachs, is opposed to labeling China as a currency manipulator and is therefore seen as a centrist.
What‚Äôs interesting is that in a statement issued after the US-China trade talks, the White House stressed that the US position was the ‚Äúconsensus‚Äù of the negotiating team, while in fact it led to more speculation about the differences within the US team during the talks. Trump has yet to set more strategies on his trade policy toward China because of differing views within the administration, according to Dr. Derek Scissors of American Enterprise Institute.
Opposition to Trump‚Äôs protectionist policies in the US business community is particularly strong because vital business interests are at stake. Not long ago, 25 well-known US retailers, including Wal-Mart, Macy‚Äôs and Best Buy, sent a letter to Trump, urging him not to impose tariffs on products imported from China so as not to harm the interests of American consumers, especially the working class, and widen the wealth gap.
Forty-five trade associations representing the interests of the US retail, technology, agriculture and other consumer goods industries also said that tariffs would increase the costs of US manufacturing, disrupt the existing supply chain, and reduce the competitiveness of US manufacturing exports, thus affecting employment in the US.
In May, when the Commerce Department launched a Section 232 investigation into imported automobiles and automobile parts, hundreds of American workers employed by foreign automakers demonstrated on Capitol Hill, and about 150 lawmakers from both sides of Congress issued a joint letter opposing the car tariffs.
Not only that, American academics have also taken action. Before the trade war broke out, 1,140 American economists, including 14 Nobel laureates, jointly wrote to Trump urging the president not to repeat the mistakes that had led to the Great Depression.
The US-China Business Council said in a statement that it agreed with the Trump administration that the status of technology transfer and protection of intellectual property rights in China do need to be taken seriously, but that US companies would like to see solutions to these problems rather than unilateral tariffs that are likely to do more significant damage to US economic interests.
Logos of US multinational technology company Apple in Vertou, western France, December 28, 2016 /VCG Photo
Governments of the affected states in the US and lawmakers representing them are worried about their own interests being damaged by Trump‚Äôs trade policy. Thanks to their relative independence, the state governments are taking steps to engage China.
On July 11, the same day the US Trade Representative released a tariff list of Chinese imports worth 200 billion US dollars, a Chicago delegation led by Mayor Rahm Emanuel visited China and signed a five-year plan to ensure that proposed investments in Chicago by Chinese enterprises will go ahead as planned. Mr. Emanuel also said in public that he hoped to boost economic and trade cooperation with China.
In Illinois, there are not only multinational companies such as Boeing, Caterpillar, McDonald‚Äôs and Abbott, but also more than 50 Chinese enterprises, including China National Cereals, Oils and Foodstuffs Corporation, Bank of China, Hainan Airlines, Fuyao Glass and Wanxiang Group.
Many US states resent Trump‚Äôs trade war with China. Michigan (where General Motors, Ford and Chrysler are headquartered), Ohio (where Procter & Gamble and American Electric are headquartered) and California (where Apple and Disney are headquartered) have all criticized Trump‚Äôs radical trade policies.
According to a survey conducted by the China General Chamber of Commerce-USA, Chinese investments in the US have created more than 200,000 jobs in Ohio, Indiana, Pennsylvania, Michigan, California and other states. On July 19, 22 governors attended the annual meeting of the National Governors Association of the US, during which they were actively engaged in discussions on how to cope with the trade war and strengthen economic and trade ties with China.
The US-China trade war will have no winners and even cause serious disruption to the global economy. While Trump has taken tough protectionist measures, not everyone in the US is in favor of his policies. To minimize the negative consequences of a trade war, consensus against it can be built up to work with those who oppose the war in the US to turn things around.
First, strengthen the role of Sino-US economic and trade cooperation as a bedrock of bilateral ties and promote consensus among US multinational companies and other interest groups.
American multinational companies have important influence on American politics. By the end of 2017, the US had invested 82.5 billion US dollars and set up 68,000 enterprises in China. The Chinese market has become an important source of growth and profits for US enterprises.
In turn, China can try to create a better environment for foreign investments, continue attracting US multinational companies to invest in China, consolidate the intertwining Sino-US economic and trade relations, and strengthen the role of Sino-US economic and trade cooperation as a bedrock of bilateral ties.
China can enhance communication with the US government through American multinational companies, trade associations, think tanks, social organizations and other entities. Furthermore, it can also get in touch with US multinational companies hurt by the trade war, to know their losses, build consensus with them and feed their opinions back to the US decision-makers, so as to resolve conundrums in Sino-US economic and trade relations and get both sides back on the track of dialogue and negotiation.
Second, strengthen provincial/state cooperation in various fields, and set up a Sino-US provincial/state government infrastructure cooperation fund.
American states and cities have a high degree of decision-making power on their own economic affairs, and have maintained close economic exchanges with China, which will be a strong supporter of positive interaction between China and the US and a firm instrument for stabilizing bilateral relations. China can encourage its provinces and cities to strengthen cooperation with their US counterparts, hold annual Sino-US governors‚Äô/mayors‚Äô summits, establish platforms and mechanisms for cooperation, and set up a Sino-US provincial/state government infrastructure cooperation fund.
The Chinese side should fully recognize the similarities and differences in the logic of political operation between the two countries, and make good use of them. In the context of Trump‚Äôs tax cuts and the quantitative easing tapering policy adopted by the Federal Reserve in the US, the need for investments, particularly those from China, will be more pressing for US state governments.
Dr. Wang Huiyao is president of the Center for China and Globalization(CCG), the largest independent think tank in China, with over 100 researchers and members of staff.
Every Chinese person knows about the gaokao. Just mention the national college entrance exam in a crowded room and watch as people recall the tears, smiles and hard work they endured.
According to official statistics, more than 70 percent of project leaders working at key national research projects are overseas returnees. A large number of academicians at Chinese Academy of Sciences and at China Academy of Engineering are overseas returnees.
Today, China is the world‚Äôs number one economy by purchasing power parity and the second-largest by official exchange rate. China is not merely the largest manufacturing and largest trading country, it is the world‚Äôs largest consumer market, and largest trading partner of more than 120 countries.
He Weiwen, deputy director of the Beijing-based Center for China and Globalization ÔºàCCGÔºâ and a former diplomat, said China faced challenges in treating foreign companies fairly and it would take time to restore their confidence.
The US should not perceive China as a rival and should stop hyping the rhetoric to gain military and political mileage, experts warned following US President Donald Trump‚Äôs first State of the Union address.
CCG is a think tank dedicated to the areas of Global trade & investment, Global migration, Global governance,Global affairs, Global talent policy.
Be sure to subscribe and listen to the other interviews as well! More exclamation points!!!! More!!!!!!!!!! Bold this time!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
